advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE II & III</strong></font><br><blockquote>From 'Personal Computing', May 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Compatible with you know who.<br> Equiped like nobody.<br> Priced like Amstrad".<br> <br> Single drive, monochrome monitor = 4997 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, monochrome monitor = 6290 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, colour monitor = 6890 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, colour monitor = 8190 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, monochrome monitor = 9990 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, colour monitor = 11890 FF + VAT</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our all-in-one BMC IF-800 computer is easier for dealers to sell, customers to buy and OEM to use in their systems...<br> ... You can upgrade to a 16 bit CPU which offers IBM PC compatible MS-DOS and CP/M-86...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE TEMPTATION...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Franklin dealer advert (1983)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #6 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TTX 80 FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"computing against wasted time"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''PB 700, the extensible personal computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (APR. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 1-2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5500 ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french advert for the ISTC 5500 published in january 1981. Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The incredible Secam color micro-computer !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''God created the world, DAI put it under CP/M''</blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Socket for an optional 68882 math coprocessor
computer.description:
The Macintosh Color Classic (aka Performa 250) had same footprint as the original Macintosh. It was the first mac using a 10" (9" viewable) colour monitor (Sony CRT) and the last of the original all-in-one Macintosh line to be sold in the US market.
Its main board had the same design as the Mac LC II, featuring a 16 MHz 68030 CPU. Sadly, its address bus was limited to 16 bit and allowed only 10 MB of maximum RAM.
The Color Classic could emulate the Apple II thank to an expansion card inserted into its PDS slot.
An improved version, called Color Classic II (aka Performa 275) was launched in late 1993 in Canada then in Japan. It had the same motherboard as the LC/Performa 550 with a 33 MHz CPU, a 32-bit bus and up to 36 MB of available RAM.
Some people call the LC/Performa 550 the "Fat Color Classic II" because of the wider monitor.
____________
Jeremy Dilatush adds: This machine's color graphics were *slow* so I usually ran mine in black and white mode. Yes, it made a major difference.
Gwion Mainwaring reports: There are PPC Upgrades available and this will make your Color Classic a lot faster so you could run Mac OS 8 or 9. OS9 would be a bit slow. But i think you can only run OS 9 on a Color Classic II.

emulator.description: Demonstration version of a commercial software (MS DOS & Win95)
emulator.name: Executor

emulator.description: A commercial Software which emulates the Atari ST/TT and the Mac 128/Plus/2 (Win95 / Win NT)
emulator.name: Gemulator

emulator.description: Same as Apple lisa emulator for unix but ported to windows
emulator.name: LisaEm

emulator.description: PearPC is an architecture-independent PowerPC platform emulator capable of running most PowerPC operating systems.
emulator.name: PearPC

emulator.description: Demo version of a commercial software (Linux / NextStep)
emulator.name: Executor
vMac - The Virtual Macintosh Emulator Project

emulator.description: Basilisk II is an Open Source 68k Macintosh emulator. Good emulator, runs on several platforms, even Amiga
emulator.name: Basilisk II

emulator.description: Mini vMac, a spin off of the program vMac, emulates a Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE. So far it works on Macintosh OS, Microsoft Windows, and the X Window System.
emulator.name: Mini vMac

computer.graphics: 512 x 384 dots. Could be expanded to 640 x 480 with significant hardware modifications.
computer.keyboard: Typewriter type 82 key with numeric keypad and arrow keys
computer.name: Macintosh Color Classic
computer.ports: 2 x ADB, 2 x serial, SCSI, sound In/Out
computer.power: Built in switching power supply unit
computer.ram: 4 MB up to 10 MB (although 12 MB could sit in the slots)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Volume and brightness adjustments are located on the front panel.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Color Classic is running Maelstrom game.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Two ADB ports - Mini-Din sockets<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Two Serial ports - Printer and modem<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> SCSI DB25 connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Sound input jack<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Sound output jack<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> The rear panel can be easily opened to slide out the motherboard<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> CRT horizontal and vertical centering<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Analog board holding the power supply unit and the video circuitry<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Intermediate bay which supports the floppy drive, the hard disk drive and the speaker<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Motherboard</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Sound chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> SCSI chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> PDS expansion slot<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Socket for the optional 68882 math coprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Motorola 68030 CPU<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Custom Apple chipset in charge of memory management and various I/O<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 1 MB ROM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Video chip and its associated 256 KB RAM<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> 4 MB on-board RAM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> SIMM socket for the video RAM expansion<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> SIMM sockets for the main RAM expansion</blockquote>

computer.sound: Mono 16-bit - Built-in speaker - sound output jack
computer.text: No text mode. Bit mapped characters
computer.vram: 256 KB up to 512 KB (specific SIMM secket)
